div.p: MEATE FOR MEN.
OR, A Principall Seruice of the SACRAMENTS.

list.item:
Wherein (amongſt many) theſe Two Points are ſpecially handled—
1. Of the Baptizing of Infants.
2. Of Kneeling in the act of Breaking and receiuing the Lords Supper.

div.p: For the vſe of all Religious Families and monethly Communicants in the Kingdome when they come to the Lords Table.
Written by way of briefe Queſtions and Anſwers, for the eaſe and benefit of the Simple.
By W. Craſhaw B. of Divinitie, and ſometimes Paſtor at White-Chappell.

p.hi: Strong Meat belongeth to them that are of age.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for G. Fayer-beard at the North doore of the Royall Exchange, 1629.

div.head: To the many thouſands of Profeſſors of CHRISTS Religion in all places in this Kingdome.
div.p: Brethren, bee not Children in vnderſtanding, howbeit in Malice bee yee Children, but in Vnderſtanding bee Men.
So teacheth you the holy Apoſtle, ſo aduiſeth, exhorteth, and prayeth for you all. A helper of your Faith, and a Seruant of your ſoules in CHRIST IESVS.

div.head: To the right Honourable, the Counteſſe of Deuonſhire, Grace and Peace.
div.p:
HAuing knowne you ſo ancient a Hearer, and which makes a true Diſciple of Chriſt, ſo carefull a practiſer of Religion, I preſumed therefore this Principall diſh of Spirituall meate, would not bee vnwelcome to you, as I know it will bee more welcome to the World, after ſo great and good a taſter as your ſelfe: And though I may ſafely ſay (as one long before mee) All Gods diſhes are dainties; yet doubtleſſe this of the Sacraments carieth with it a peculiar Excellencie: And I bring it in firſt, not that there are not others to come in before it, but for the generall vſe and preſent neceſſitie of it euen at this time: That this may ſerue firſt to ſtay and comfort many weake and then
if it may bee, to ſatisfie certaine curious and ſqueaſie ſtomackes amongſt vs: Who ſome of them about the Sacrament of Baptiſme, others in ſome circumſtantiall matters concerning the Lords Supper, haue kindled ſuch a fire of contention in the Church, as now diuers of them would bee glad with many teares to quench if they knew how. It hath pleaſed God who workes euen by weake meanes, by my words in publike and priuate to ſatiſfie many, if by writing alſo I may doe good to them that cannot heare mee, let the glory bee His, the comfort theirs, and the ſeruice acceptable to the Church; So the labour ſhall willingly bee mine: and I ſhall take joy and comfort in ſuch courſes, in Pulpit and by Penne, Preaching, writing, and conferring to ſpend and end the few dayes I haue remaining, and ſo to make ready for a better life. And wherein (Madame) any of my labours may be ſeruiceable to you or yours. Commaund mee,

closer.signed: Your ſeruant in Chriſt, W. CRASHAVV.

div.head: The points here handled are theſe.

row.cell: Of the Nature of a Sacrament.
Of the Sacraments of the Old Teſtament, and who hath power to ordaine a Sacrament.
Of the Sacraments of the New Teſtament, and the Relation betwixt them and thoſe of the Old.
What be the eſſentiall parts of a Sacrament.
Of the nature and vſe of Baptiſme.
Of the outward and inward things in Baptiſme.
Of the difference betwixt Baptiſme and the Lords Supper,
That Children may and ought to bee Baptized.
Of the Names and Nature of the Lords Supper,
Of the outward Elements in the Lords Supper.
Of Bread and the excellent reſemblance, betwixt it and the Body of Chriſt.
Of Wine and the notable correſpondencie, betwixt it and the Bloud of Christ,
Of the outward actions to bee performed in the Miniſtration of the Lords Supper,
Of the inward actions Spirituall, which are performed in this Sacrament, betwixt God and the Soule of the worthy Receiuer,
What preparation is neceſſarie in regard of God, to make a man a worthy Receiuer,
What preparation is requiſite in regard of our Brethren,
Of the Circumſtances obſeruable in this Sacrament,
That kneeling in the very act of Breaking, giuing and Receiuing, is not onely lawfull but conuenient & commendable,
What a Chriſtian man is to doe, when hee hath Receiued.

div.head: MEATE FOR MEN.
CHAP. 1.

argument.p: Of Faith.

div.head: Queſtion. WHat is the end of a Chriſtian mans life?
div.p: Anſwer. The ſaluation of his 1. Pet. 1. 9. Soule.

div.head: Q. How can a man bee ſaued? Seing he is a Sinner?
div.p: A. By true Faith in CHRIST. Rom. 3. 22, &c. 1. Ioh. 5 4. 1. Sam 8. 3, 4, 5.

div.head: Q. How come wee by this Faith?
div.p: A. It neither comes by Nature from our Parents, nor by humaine inſtruction from any Teachers, nor by imitation of them that haue it.

div.head: Q. How then muſt wee get it?
div.p: A. It is the guift of God. Heb. 12. 2.

div.head: Q. Doth God giue it to all men?
div.p: A. No, all men haue not Faith: no 2. Theſ. 3. 8 not all that bee in the Church.

div.head: Q. To whom then belongs it?
div.p: A. To thoſe that are the Elect of God. Tit. 1, 1.

div.head: Q. How doth God giue it them?
div.p: A. By meanes of his owne appointing 1. Cor. 1. 21 he doth begin and encreaſeth it.

div.head: Q. Is it not then perfect at the firſt?
div.p: A. No: it is true, but not perfect, for Tim. 1, 5. Rom. 4. 19. 20. Mat. 14. 31. Faith is firſt weake, and afterward becomes a ſtrong Faith.

div.head: Chap. 2.

argument.p: How Faith is wrought.

div.head: Queſtion. BY what meanes doth God begin or beget Faith in his Children?
div.p: A. Ordinarily, by hearing the Word Rom 10, 12. 1. Cor. 1. 21 preached.

div.head: Q. By what parts of his word, the Law or Goſpell?
div.p: A. By both: for the law begins, and Gal. 3, 23, 24. Rom. 7. 24, 25. the Goſpell finiſheth that worke.

div.head: Q. How is that done?
div.p: A. The Law prepares the hart by humbling it, and making it a contrite heart.

div.head: Q. How doth the Law humble the heart?
div.p: A. By ſhewing a Man Gods Iuſtice, Rom. 7, 9, 10 11. and his owne ſinnes.

div.head: Q. And how doth the Goſpell finiſh the worke of faith?
div.p: A. It purifies the heart of man, and Acts. 15. 9. 1. Ioh. 3, 3 makes it a new heart.

div.head: Q. How doth the Goſpell purge the heart?
div.p: A. By letting vs ſee the great loue of 2. Cor. 2. 14 15 1. Pet. 1. 22 God in Ieſus Chriſt.

div.head: Q. Can then the Preachers of the Word giue this Faith?
div.p: A. No. they preach the Word, but it's 1. Cor. 3, 5, 6, 7. onely God that inſpires Faith.

div.head: Q. How may a man know that hee hath true Faith?
div.p: A His Soule muſt bee inflamed with Ioh, 7. 37 38 a holy deſire to pleaſe God, and to doe all good workes.

div.head: Chap. 3.

argument.p: How Faith is maintained and encreaſed.

div.head: Queſtion. HOw doth God maintaine and encreaſe Faith in his Children.
div.p: A. By diuers meanes, whereof ſome are principall, and ſome inferiour.

div.head: Q. What bee the principall meanes?
div.p: A. Two: the continuall Preaching of Mat. 28. 19. Acts. 2, 41 1. Theſ. 3. 11 12, 13 the ſame Word: and the holy vſe of the Sacraments.

div.head: Q. And what be the Inferiour meanes?
div.p: A. Three: 1. The reading of Gods Ioh. 5. Word.
2. Holy conferences with holy men. Heb. 10. 24 25 Lam. 3. 22, 23. 24. Zeph. 3, 5 Pſal. 107.
3. Daily obſeruation of Gods Mercies and Iudgements, and meditation vpon the ſame.

div.head: Q. How differ theſe?
div.p: A. The principall are publicke, and performed by Gods Miniſters: the other are dayly to bee practiſed by our ſelues in priuate.

div.head: Q. How differ the Word and Sacraments?
div.p: A. Thus: the word containes the Heb 13. 20 Rom. 4, 11. Couenants of God: and the Sacraments are ſeales confirming that Couenant of our ſoules.
Againe, the Word is the holy and internall Iam. 1. 18. Ioh. 1. 13 1. Pet. 1, 23. ſeed of our Regeneration, and by Sacraments we are borne anew, and fed vp for Heauen.

div.head: Chap. 4.

argument.p: Of the Nature of a Sacrament in Generall.

div.head: Queſtion. IS not the Preaching of the Word ſufficient for Faith?
div.p: A. No▪ the Sacraments muſt alſo bee Rom, 3, 1, 10 14 receiued as Couenants after they be made muſt be ſealed.

div.head: Q. What are the Sacraments in their generall nature?
div.p: A. Outward viſible ſignes of inward, Gen. 17. Exod, 12. and inuiſible graces.

div.head: Q. What be they in regard of God?
div.p: A. Tokens of his loue, pledges of his fauour▪ and ſeales of his Couenant.

div.head: Q. What be they in regard of Chriſt?
div.p: A. Commemorations of his death, and 1. Cor. 11. 24 25, 26 applications of the vertue thereof vnto our ſelues.

div.head: Q And what be they in regard of vs?
div.p: A. Seales of his Couenants betwixt Rom. 4, •• . God and vs: and effectuall meanes to ſtrengthen our Faith, and all other holy graces in vs.

div.head: Chap. 5.

argument.p: Of the Sacraments of the old Teſtament, and to whom it belongs to ordaine a Sacrament.

div.head: Queſtion. MAy the Church ordaine Sacraments?
div.p: A. No, it belongs to God, as a Exod. 14. Gen. 17. part of his Prerogatiue.

div.head: Q. Why may God alone ordaine Sacraments?
div.p: A. Becauſe they bee Seales of his Couenants, tokens of his loue, and parts of his worſhip.

div.head: Q. How many bee the Sacraments of the new Teſtament?
div.p: A. As many as were the ordinary Sacrament of the old; namely two,

div.head: Q. Which were the ordinary Sacraments of the old Teſtament?
div.p: A. Circumciſion, and the Paſſeouer.

div.head: Q. Why do you call them extraordinary. Gen. 17 Exod. 12.
div.p: A. Becauſe there were extraordinary?

div.head: Q. How did they differ?
div.p:
A. Thus: the extraordinary were ſuch as God ordained vpon ſome ſpeciall
occaſion, & were to laſt but for that time Exod. as the Manna, the Rocke, the Cloud, &c.

div.head: Q▪ And what then were the ordinary?
div.p: A. Such as were alwayes in force, from the time of their ordination till Chriſts comming.

div.head: Chap. 6.

argument.p: Of the Sacraments of the new Teſtament, and a compariſon with them of the Old.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat be the Sacraments of the new Teſtament?
div.p: A. Theſe two: Baptiſme, and the Lords Supper.

div.head: Q. What ſay you then to Confirmation and marriage, and the reſt of the fiue Sacraments of the Romane Church?
div.p: A. They are ſome of them Gods holy ordinances, and ſome of them may be holy ſignes, but they were neuer ordained by Chriſt for Sacraments, nor euer ſo vſed in the ancient Church.

div.head: Q. How doe theſe anſwere to thoſe of the old Teſtament?
div.p: A. Thus our Baptiſme anſweres to 1, Pet. 3, 21 Circumciſion, and the Lords Supper ſucceeds in the roome of the Paſſe ouer.

div.head: Q How differ theſe from thoſe?
div.p: A. Nothing at all in matters of efficacy or power, but onely in manner and 1, Cor. 10, 3 4 circumſtance, for thoſe did point at Chriſt to come, ours at Chriſt come already.

div.head: Q. What need then was there, to haue any other in the new Teſtament?
div.p: A. Becauſe the Sacraments are Seales of Gods Couenant, and its fit that the Heb. 7, 8, 9. Couenant being renewed, the Seales alſo ſhould be new.

div.head: Chap. 7.

argument.p: Of the eſſentiall parts of a Sacrament.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat bee the eſſentiall parts of euery Sacrament?
div.p: A. Two: one outward and viſible, the other inward and inuiſible repreſented thereby.

div.head: Q. What outward things bee there in euery Sacrament?
div.p: A. Theſe, 1. A viſible Miniſter, a Man called therunto of God.
2. Some viſible Elements ordained of God.
3. Some outward actions appointed by God.

div.head: Q And what ſpirituall and inuiſible?
div.p: A Theſe: 1. The inuiſible God repreſented by the Miniſter.
2. Some holy grace or bleſſing repreſented by the Element.
3. Some gracious workes of God repreſented by the externall actions of the Miniſter.

div.head: Q What circumſtances or Ceremonies are required in the Sacraments?
div.p: A. Such as the Church ſhall appoint by lawfull authoritie.

div.head: Chap. 8.

argument.p: Of the Nature and vſe of Baptiſme.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat is Baptiſme?
div.p: A. The word ſignifieth a waſhing Heb. 9. 10 with water.

div.head: Q. What is the Sacrament of Baptiſme?
div.p: A. In it owne generall nature, it is Acts. 2. 38 a waſhing of the body in the name of the Lord.

div.head: Q. And what is it in regard of God?
div.p: A. A badge or cognizance which God ſets vpon ſuch as hee takes to bee his ſeruants.

div.head: Q. And what is it in regard of Chriſt?
div.p: A. An application of the vertue of his 1. Cor. 5. 7. bloud-ſhedding, to cleanſe the Soule from the guilt of Originall ſinne.

div.head: Q. And what is Baptiſme in reſpect of our ſelues?
div.p: A. The Sacrament of our entrance, or Admiſſion into the Couenant and Church of God.

div.head: Q. When may Baptiſme bee adminiſtred?
div.p: A. At any time if there bee cauſe: but ordinarily when the Congregation is aſſembled to worſhip God.

div.head: Chap. 9.

argument.p: Of the outward and inward things in Baptiſme.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat is the outward and viſible Element in Baptiſme?
div.p: A. Water: and nothing but water.

div.head: Q What is the outward action?
div.p: A. To waſh the Body in water. 1. Pet. 3. 21▪

div.head: Q. Why is not better liquor to bee vſed, as milke or bloud?
div.p: A. Becauſe waſhing is the effect of 1. Cor. 5. 7. this Sacrament, and thoſe may be better for feeding, but not for waſhing.

div.head: Q. What is the inward and inviſible things?
div.p: A. The bloud of Chriſt. Reu. 1. 5. 1. Pet. 3. 21:

div.head: Q. What is the ſpirituall action in Baptiſme?
div.p: A. The cleanſing or purging of the 1. Ioh. 1, 7 19. Soule by the bloud of Chriſt.

div.head: Q Who is the outward Miniſter of this Sacrament?
div.p: A. He that is alſo a Miniſter of the Acts. 2. 41. Mat. 28. 19. Word, for theſe 2 muſt both goe together.

div.head: Q. Who is the Miniſter of the inward Baptiſme?
div.p: A. The Lord Ieſus, who hath waſhed vs from our ſinnes in his bloud.

div.head: Q Where is the Inſtitution of Baptiſme ſet downe in the Scripture.
div.p: A. In the Goſpell, where Chriſt after his Reſurrection commands his Apoſtles. Mat. 28. 18, 19, 20. Go teach all Nations, Baptizing them in the name of the Father, of the Son, and of the holy Ghoſt.

div.head: Chap. 10.

argument.p: Of the difference betwixt Baptiſme, and the Lords Supper.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat difference is there betwixt Baptiſme and the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. 1. Baptiſme is the Sacrament of our new birth: and the Lords Supper of our ſpirituall growth.
2. Baptiſme is the Sacrament of our Admiſſion, the Lords Supper of our Confirmation in the ſtate of Grace.

div.head: Q. What other difference is there?
div.p: A. This: Baptiſme muſt euer be firſt, and the Lords Supper muſt come after.

div.head: Q. What reaſon is there for that?
div.p: A. It is neceſſary that one bee firſt borne, afore he be fed.

div.head: Q. Is there any other difference?
div.p: A. Yes: Baptiſme ſufficeth to bee once adminiſtred. But the Lords Supper is often requiſite.

div.head: Q. What reaſon may be thereof?
div.p: A. Becauſe, it ſufficeth to bee once borne, but being borne, it is neceſſary to be often fed.

div.head: Q. Is there no other difference?
div.p: A. Yes, Children may bee Baptized, but may not Communicate: as a Child may be borne, but is not fit for all food.

div.head: Chap. 11.

argument.p: Who are to bee Baptized.

div.head: Queſtion. WHo are to be Baptized?
div.p: A. All that are capable of it? Acts. 2. 41. and 8. 36.

div.head: Q. Who are capable of it?
div.p: A. All that beleeue in Chriſt, and deſire Acts, 8. 36. Mark. 16. 16 Acts. 10, 47 Acts. 8. 36 & 2. 41. Baptiſme.

div.head: Q. How is Baptiſme to be deſired?
div.p: A. They that bee of yeares muſt profeſſe their owne faith, and deſire it themſelues. Infants of Beleeuers doe it by Mark. 10, 13 their Parents, or witneſſes & vndertakers.

div.head: Q. May all challenge Baptiſme that be thus made capable?
div.p: A. Yes, aſſuredly, for it is the ſpirituall Acts, 8. 36. Mark. 10 14 15, birth-right to all Beleeuers.

div.head: Q. May not Turkes nor Iewes nor Heathen be Baptized?
div.p: A. No, becauſe they beleeue not in Mark. 16, 16 Chriſt. but when they doe they may.

div.head: Q But may the Children of Papiſts bee Baptized?
div.p: A. Yes▪ becauſe they profeſſe Chriſt Acts. 8. 37. Ieſus according to the Apoſtles Creed, though they doe by other doctrine and practiſes adulterate and corrupt it.

div.head: Q. Is Baptiſme neceſſary to Saluation?
div.p: A Not ſimplie neceſſary to Children, Gen. 17. 12 2. Sam. 12. 18. and. 23. no more then Circumciſion was in the old Teſtament.

div.head: Q. How then is it neceſſary?
div.p: A. To all them that can aske it, and Mark. 16. 16 may haue it, it is abſolutely neceſſary, ſo as without it there is no Saluation.

div.head: Chap. 12.

argument.p: That Children may be Baptized.

div.head: Queſtion. BƲt may Infants be Baptized?
div.p: A. Yes, the Infants of beleeuing Parents.

div.head: Q. How may that bee ſeeing they haue no Faith.
div.p: A. That is more then we know, for God may worke Faith in their Soules immediately. Iohn. 3, 8.

div.head: Q. But if they haue Faith, yet they cannot profeſſe it.
div.p: A. Their Parents and witneſſes profeſſe it for them. Gen. 17

div.head: Q But how can Children enter into a Couenant with God?
div.p: A. Very well: for a man may couenant Heb. 7. 9, 10 for himſelfe and his Children, and that act of the Parents is ye Childrens act.

div.head: Q. But how is it proued that the Infant of the beleeuing Parents may be Baptized?
div.p: A. By many Arguments:
1 By Gods owne practiſe, who commanded Gen. 17. 9 to 13. children to bee Circumciſed at eight dayes old, in the Old Teſtament.
2 By the tenor of his Couenant Gen. 17. 7 which runnes thus; I will be thy God, and the God of thy ſeed.
3 By the practiſe of Chriſt, who tooke Mark. 10, 13 them vp in his armes and bleſſed them; now if they bee capable of Chriſts bleſſings, they are capable of Baptiſme.
4 By the practiſe of Gods Church, in the pureſt and beſt times.

div.head: Chap. 13.

argument.p: Of the Names and Nature of the Lords Supper.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat is the ſecond Sacrament of the new Teſtament?
div.p: A. The Euchariſt, or Communion, of the Lords Supper.

div.head: Q. What is that?
div.p: A. The Sacrament of our Confirmation or Celebration in Gods Church, by which our Soules are dayly fed vp in the hope of Heauen, and aſſurance of Gods loue to vs in Chriſt.

div.head: Q. Why is it called the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. Becauſe Chriſt ordained it, and began Mat. 26. 26. it at his laſt Supper.

div.head: Q. And why is it called the Communion?
div.p: A. Becauſe not one alone receiues it, as in Baptiſme, but alwayes many together 1. Cor. 10. 16. 17. doe Communicate.

div.head: Q. But why is it called the Euchariſt, or Thanks-giuing?
div.p: A. Becauſe, as alwayes, ſo now eſpecially wee haue cauſe to offer vp our beſt thanks to God for our Redemption by Chriſt,

div.head: Q. To whom belongs this Sacrament?
div.p: A. To all, that being baptized can and 1. Cor. 11. 28 doe prepare themſelues for it.

div.head: Q. May all ſuch challenge it?
div.p:
A. Yes, as all Iewes had their part in Exod, 12. 3. 4. 6.
the Paſſeouer; and therefore in old time, it was not vnworthily called by the people their Writings, for indeed it doth of Right belong vnto them.

div.head: Chap. 14.

argument.p: Of the outward Elements in the Lords Supper.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat be the outward viſible Elements in the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. Bread and Wine. Math. 26. 26 1. Cor. 11. 23

div.head: Q. Are there no other?
div.p: A. Chriſt ordained neither more nor fewer, whatſoeuer the Romane Church ſaith.

div.head: Q. Where is the Inſtitution of this Sacrament?
div.p: A. In three of the Goſpels, and it is Math. 26. Mar. 14 Luk. 22 2. Cor. 11. repeated by Saint Paul, after Chriſts aſcention.

div.head: Q. What is the inward, inuiſible and ſpirituall bleſſing?
div.p: A. Chriſt Ieſus his Body and Bloud, 1. Cor. 10. 16 with all the merits of the ſame.

div.head: Q. What Bread is fitteſt in the Sacrament?
div.p: A. The beſt and pureſt feeding bread.

div.head: Q. And what Wine?
div.p: A. That which is moſt cheriſhing and comfortable, and doth moſt neerely reſemble bloud.

div.head: Q Are wee tyed to any faſhion or kind of Bread?
div.p: A. Such as the Church ſhall appoint.

div.head: Q. Ought there to bee Water mingled with the Wine?
div.p: A. No: Chriſt appointed no ſuch thing.

div.head: Q. But may it be done at all?
div.p: A. Yes, in caſe of neceſſitie, as:

list.item: 1. When there is want of wine.
2. When ſome be ſo weake, they cannot endure Wine.

div.head: Chap. 15.

argument.p: Of the Bread, and how it reſembleth Chriſts Body.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHy did the Lord appoint Bread, and Wine, rather then any other things?
div.p:
A. For two cauſes; namely, their generalitie,
and ſignificancie aboue other Creatures that are eaten and drunke.

div.head: Q. How appeares this generality?
div.p: A. Thus: of all Creatures that men Mat. 4. 4. Deutr. 8. 3. eate or drinke, theſe are moſt generally knowne, moſt vniuerſally vſed, and moſt eaſily come by.

div.head: Q But what is their ſignificancie?
div.p: A. This: that theſe two creatures do moſt plainely ſignifie, and moſt liuely reſemble the body and bloud of Chriſt, of 1. Cor. 10. 16 17. any Creatures in the world.

div.head: Q. How doth the Bread reſemble Chriſt his Body and ſufferings.
div.p: A. Moſt liuely: in many particulars: Ioh. 6. 41. and therefore hee is called the Bread that came downe from heauen.

div.head: Q Shew the firſt reſemblance?
div.p: A. Bread reliſheth all other meats, ſo Chriſt giues the true ſauour and reliſh 1. Cor. 1. 30 to all other bleſſings.

div.head: Q Declare the ſecond?
div.p: A. No meate is wholeſome to the Body, without Bread: no more is any bleſſing to the Soule, without Chriſt.

div.head: Q. Adde the third?
div.p:
A. Moſt meates hurt the Body eaten without Bread, and the more outward
bleſſings without Chriſt, the more hurtfull to the Soule.

div.head: Q. What is the next reſemblance?
div.p: A. Bread and wine alone feeds the Body, Philip. 4, 11 12, 13. if one haue no other meate.
So Chriſt alone giues feeding and contentment to the Soule, if a man had nothing elſe.

div.head: Q. What proportion is there elſe betwixt Bread, and the holy Body of Chriſt?
div.p: A. This Bread ſtrengthens the heart, Pſal, 104. 15. other meates feeds other humours, but Bread is the ſtrength of Nature.
So other bleſſings ſerue for other vſes Pſal. Philip, 4, 13, but Chriſt is the ſtrength of the Soule.

div.head: Q. Goe forward is there any more?
div.p: A. Yes: Bread is meat for all men, ſeuerall Deut. 8. 3 meates are for ſeuerall ſorts of men, but bread for all.
So, ſome bleſſings are for ſome, ſome 2. Tim, 2, 6, Ioh. 4, 15. 16 1. Ioh. 2, 2 for others, but Chriſt for all: all that eate him haue equall title in him.

div.head: Q. Is there yet any other point of reſemblance?
div.p: A Yes: Bread feeds not till it haue paſt and endured the violence of all the Elements, and as it were dyed many deaths.
So Chriſt the Bread that came downe Ioh. 3. 14. 15 &c, from Heauen, is not a Sauior of our Soules till he haue ſuffered all kind of ſufferings.

div.head: Chap. 16.

argument.p: Of Wine, and how it reſembleth the Bloud of Chriſt.

div.head: Queſtion. HOw doth the Wine reſemble the Bloud of Chriſt?
div.p: A. Firſt, in name and colour, being therfore called the bloud of the grape:

div.head: Q. And is not that all?
div.p: A. No, it is alſo like in nature and opperation, for firſt, Wine is not Wine till it be preſſed out of the grape
So Chriſts bloud is not effectuall, but Heb. 9, 12. 13, 14 being preſſed out of his bleſſed body.

div.head: Q. Show the next reſemblance?
div.p: A. Wine is fit drinke for the ſorrowfull Prou. 31, 6, and heauie hearted man-
So Chriſts bloud is ſweeteſt to the ſorrowfull Pſal. 51, 17. Math. 9. 13 Soule, and humbled heart.

div.head: Q. Is there any other reſemblance?
div.p: A. Yes. Wine cheriſheth the heart of Pſal, 104, 15 man.

So the Spirituall Wine, the bloud of
Chriſt comforts the diſtreſſed conſcience.

div.head: Q. It ſeemes then the people ought to haue Wine as well as the Bread?
div.p: A. Yea, rather they then the Clergie, Math. 9. 12. as weake ones haue more need of Wine then the ſtrong and healthfull.

div.head: Q. It ſeemes the people haue need of it, but by what right can they challenge it?
div.p: A. By a double right, 1. By the inſtitution Math 26. 26 27. 28. 1. Cor. 11. 25 and 28. of Chriſt, who ſo ordained it, 2. By the practiſe of the Primitiue Church, for 1000. yeeres after Chriſt.

div.head: Chap. 17.

argument.p: Of the outward actions in the Lords Supper.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat bee the outward actions to bee performed in the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. They be of two ſorts: ſome to be done by the Miniſter, ſome by the Receiuer.

div.head: Q. What is the Miniſter to doe?
div.p: A. Foure things.

list.item: 1. To take Bread and Wine. Mat. 26. 26. &c.
2. To bleſſe them.
3. To breake the Bread, and poure out the Wine. 1. Cor. 11. 26. &c.
4. To giue them to the Communicants, to euery one ſeuerally.

div.head: Q. And what belongs to the Receiuer?
div.p: A. Two things.

list.item: 1. To take them both. Mat. 26. 26. &c. 1. Cor. 11. 23 &c.
2. To eate and drinke them in remembrance of the breaking of Chriſts body, and ſhedding of his bloud.

div.head: Q. And is not the Miniſter to hold it vp, to be ſeene and worſhipped of the people.
div.p: A. No, Chriſt commanded no ſuch thing, but it came in together with Idolatry.

div.head: Q. But is not the people to worſhip it when it is conſecrated?
div.p: A. No, that were foule Idolatry to Deut. 2. 2 worſhip Bread?

div.head: Q. But it is not Bread but God?
div.p: A. Nay, if it were God it might not bee eaten with the Mouth.

div.head: Q. But may not the people keepe part of it, and carrie it home?
div.p: A. No, it is impietie, and ſuperſtition: and Chriſt commanded no more, but to take and eate.

div.head: Chap. 18.

argument.p: Of the inward actions in the Lords Supper.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat be the ſpirituall and inward actions in the Sacrament?
div.p: A. Anſwerable to the outward: ſome belong to the Giuer, ſome to the Receiuer.

div.head: Q Who is the inuiſible Miniſter here?
div.p: A. God the Father, giuing Chriſt vnto Rom. 8. 32. vs.

div.head: Q. What are the actions he doth?
div.p: A. Foure: Anſwerable to the foure outward things done by the Miniſter.
1 He deſtinates Chriſt to be our Sauiour, repreſented by the Miniſters taking of bread and wine.
2 He ſanctifies Chriſts humanity, and Ioh. 3, 34 furniſheth it with holineſſe: ſhadowed by the Miniſters bleſſing of the Eliments.
3 He giues his Sonne to dye, and to be Rom. 8, 32▪ broken for vs, liuely reſembled in breaking the Bread and pouring out the Wine.

4 He offers that crucified Sonne, to 1. Cor. 1. 30 euery beleeuing ſoule, as is moſt comfortably repreſented vnto vs in the
Miniſters giuing of the broken bread to each Communicant.

div.head: Q. And what be the ſpirituall actions of the Receiuer?
div.p: A. Spiritually by Faith, and Loue, to Iohn, 9. 53, &c. to 56▪ take and eate him, that is to make him our owne, as Bread is when a man hath eaten it, and receiues life and ſtrength by it.

div.head: Chap. 19.

argument.p: What Preparation is requiſite in regard of God.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHo receiue benefit by this Sacrament?
div.p: A. The worthy Receiuer: Many receiue it, but none elſe receiue benefit by it.

div.head: Q. Who is the worthy Receiuer hereof?
div.p: A. He that beleeuing in Chriſt, doth rightly prepare himſelfe thereunto.

div.head: Q. What is requiſite to a right preparation?
div.p: A. Two ſorts of things:

list.item: 1 Some betwixt God and our ſelues.
2 Some betwixt our neighbours and vs.

div.head: Q. What is required in regard of God?
div.p: A. Seauen things:

list.item: 1. A competent meaſure of knowledge 1, Chr. 28. 9 of the principles of Religion.
2. A ſerious examination of our hearts 2. Cor. 13. 5 Gal. 6. 4. and liues, to know our corruptions and ſinnes.
3. True confeſſion of them all to God Pſalm, 51. 4. Iames 5. 16. and to man alſo where we find need.
4 A clenſing of our hearts by renewing Iam. 4▪ 8 Exod. 12. 8. of our repentance.
5 A trimming of our ſoules by holy reſolutions, Reuel. 21. 2. Ierem. and loue of vertue.
6 A raiſing vp of our hearts to a meditation i. Sam. 12. 24 of Gods mercies to vs in Chriſt.
7 A reſolution to become new creatures, 2. Th. 5. 23. and to practiſe new obedience euery day more and more.

div.head: Chap. 20.

argument.p: What preperation is requiſite in regard of our Brethren.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHat preparation is fit in reſpect of our Neighbours?
div.p: A. To be in Chriſtian loue and charitie Exod. 12. 8. Heb. 12. 14. with all men: and at peace alſo if it be poſſible.

div.head: Q. How can we loue euill men?
div.p: A. We muſt loue good men in God, Math. 5. and euill men for God: yea though they be our cruell enemies.

div.head: Q▪ What ſhall they doe that haue Law ſaite • ?
div.p: A. Eyther preſently end them, or 1. Cor. 6. learne to goe to Law without breach of Charitie.

div.head: Q. How may one doe ſo?
div.p: A. Thus:

list.item: 1 Neuer going to Law for ſmall things. Prou.
2 Making Law the laſt meanes of getting right.
3 To be euer ready to make a quiet end Pſal, 34. 14. to ſome loſſe.

div.head: Q. What if a man ſee he cannot goe to Law without breach of Charitie?
div.p: A. Till he can, hee muſt haue no Iohn, 6. 27, ſutes, nor rob God of his worſhip to enrich himſelfe.

div.head: Q. What muſt hee doe that is at variance with another?
div.p: A. Seeke to be reconciled. Mat. 5.

div.head: Q. What if the other will not bee reconciled?
div.p:
A. Let him ſhew himſelfe ready for Gal. 6. 5. his part, and God will accept him: and
leaue the other to God and the Church to deale withall.

div.head: Chap. 21.

argument.p: Of the Circumſtanes of this Sacrament.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHether is it neceſſary to receiue faſting?
div.p: A. It is conuenient, not neceſſary.

div.head: Q. How appeares that?
div.p: A. Thus:

list.item: 1 If one be not well, God ſaith hee will Math. 9. 3, haue mercy and not Sacrifice.
2 Becauſe meate defiles not a man.
3 In the primitiue Church they receiued at any time, day or night.

div.head: Q. Muſt we follow Chriſt in all things toucbing this Sacrament?
div.p: A. For matter of ſubſtance wee muſt, but for circumſtances not ſo.

div.head: Q. What bee the ſubſtantiall matters in this Sacrament?
div.p: A. Foure: 2. Perſons, and 2. things.

div.head: Q What be the Perſons?
div.p: A, A Miniſter qualified to giue it, and a worthy Receiuer to take it.

div.head: Q▪ What be the the things?
div.p: A. The Elements, and the actions to be done about thoſe Elements.
Theſe may not be altered.

div.head: Q. But why are wee not tyed alſo to follow Chriſt, in the circumſtances of time, place, geſture, number, ſexe, vnleauened Bread, &c.
div.p: A. Becauſe Chriſt was tyed to the Circumſtances of the Paſſe-ouer, ſo are not wee.

div.head: Q. Why was Chriſt bound to keepe the Paſſe ouer?
div.p: A. Becauſe hee was a Iew borne, and came to fulfill all righteouſneſſe.

div.head: Q. But the Paſſe-ouer was a Ceremonie?
div.p: A. True: but the Ceremonicall Law was in ſorce vntill Chriſt dyed.

div.head: Chap 22.

argument.p: That kneeling is not onely lawfull but conuement and commendable.

div.head: Queſtion. VVHo then is to appoint the Circumſtances for this Sacrament?
div.p: A. The Church hath power to doe it.

div.head: Q. How appeares?
div.p: A. Becauſe Shee is the Spouſe, and Math. 28. 20 hath the Spirit and power of Chriſt.

div.head: Q What time hath the Church appointed as beſt?
div.p: A. The morning, becauſe we are then fitteſt for any great or good action. Pſal.

div.head: Q. And what place?
div.p: A. The publicke Congregation, except in caſe of neceſſitie. Pſal, 40

div.head: Q And what geſture is beſt and fitteſt?
div.p: A. The geſture of moſt Humilitie; namely, kneeling.

div.head: Q▪ Why is kneeling the beſt beſeeming geſture?
div.p: A Becauſe wee then ſhow the Lords 1. Cor. 11. 28 death, who dyed by our meanes, and for our fault: therefore wee may not ſhow that death, but with all humility.

div.head: Q. But is it not Idolatry to kneele to the Bread?
div.p: A. We kneele to no Bread, but onely Iames. to God, to whom alſo we then pray.

div.head: Q. But did not the Pope bring in kneeling, together with Tranſubſtantiation?
div.p: A. No, it was vſed by deuout and holy Chriſtians long before: as may appeare in the end of this Booke.

div.head: Q. But is it not a Feaſt, and therefore more fit to ſit then kneele?
div.p: A. Firſt, the Scripture calls it not a 1 Cor. 11. 28 Feaſt, but a commemoration of the Lords death.
Secondly, if it bee a Feaſt, its like a Funerall feaſt where is cauſe of Sorrow as well as Ioy.

Thirdly, the concluſion certainly is a 1. Cor. 11. 28 Feaſt, but not the breaking, giuing, and taking: That is a ſhowing of the Lords death, and therefore it is to be done kneeling: But that done, then it is a Communion and Loue-feaſt, and then wee may either ſit and ſing, or ſtand and praiſe 1 Cor. 10. 16 GOD.

div.head: Q. But why ſhould wee alter the geſture that Christ vſed?
div.p: A. It is not certaine Chriſt gaue it them ſitting, the Text ſaith not ſo.
Againe, Saint Paul repeating all hee receiued 2 Cor. 11. 23 of Chriſt, ſaith not a word of any geſture.
Third, If it were certain, yet the Church vpon good cauſe might as well alter it, as the Bread, time, place &c.

div.head: Q. What is to bee thought of them that wilfully refuſe to kneele?
div.p: A. They are like rebellious, and proud children, that will take vpon them to ouer-rule their Mother.

div.head: Q. May one alone Communicate?
div.p: A. No, there muſt bee a conuenient 1. Cor. 10. 16, 17. number, elſe it is no Communion.

div.head: Chap▪ 23.

argument.p: What a Chriſtian ought to doe after he hath Receiued.

div.head: Queſtion. WHat is to bee done, when wee haue Receiued?
div.p: A. In the Church wee are to giue God Heb. 13. 15. 1. Cor. 16. Heb. 3. 16. thankes, with the Congregation, and to offer vp our Aimes for the poore.

div.head: Q Who are to giue almes when they receiue?
div.p: A. All that come to take part in Chriſt, Wiues, women, and ſeruants, are all to giue ſomething to Chriſts poore members, Gal. 3. 28. ſeeing hee giues himſelfe to all without difference.

div.head: Q. How and what is euery one to giue?
div.p: A. According to the neceſſities of the 2. Cor. 8. 2. & 9. 7. 1. Cor. 16. 2. poore, and as God hath bleſſed thee that Moneth, or ſince thou didſt laſt receiue.

div.head: Q And what is to bee done at home?
div.p: A. Retire your ſelues in priuate, and meditate vpon the infinite mercy of God, in giuing Chriſt to dye for our ſinnes, and Pſal. 44. Math. 6. 6. 1. Theſ. 4. 12 to begge grace, that daily we may walke worthy of it.

div.head: Q▪ But as wee receiued together in the Church, it is not fit to goe together that day to drinke and make merry?
div.p: A. Thankfulneſſe is neceſſarie, and moderate mirth is lawfull, but as this is 1. Theſ. 5. 18 Philip. 3. Ioh. 6. 2. a Spirituall feaſt, ſo our joy that day is to bee Spirituall: There bee other dayes enough for the body.
